div1.p:
Dearest family - Am going to get busy and write you the very first thing this Sunday. It is just noon by Gatlingburg time but you know we are a good half hour slower than the real time as the people here go by the sun and later on we will be a half hour ahead of everyone else. We have just finished dinner - Mrs. Bishop - Emily - Evelyn & I with - Aunt Lizzie too of course and are now scattered to various occupations. Sunday School began about nine and lasted nearly two hours as there was business connected with it in regard w the teachers & officers. They are so slow & deliberate - none of the youngsters will take part in things. I was in Evelyn's class for a change this morning - Mrs. Bishop took a class of grown ups - there is a class of men under our
"chorister" and superintendent Mr. Lawson Reagan - and Evelyn's class of older girls - another of big boys - a class of girls & boys from 8 to 14 & another of little tots. Think our attendance averages about 50. More turn out for B.Y.P.U. Sunday evenings. Wish I could give you a pen picture of it all - Most of us sit in the choir seats before and after the lesson & sing & sing & sing! Am developing considerable lung power & guess my vocal lessons were not amiss after all. During dinner today we got to talking about our New Orleans trip - Told you that Emily was going with me Christmas & Mrs. Bishop told Evelyn she aught to go too & put off her northern trip till later. And Evelyn is persuaded & we are going to let the Pi Phis along the way know about our coming to let them "be nice" to us and tell them
all about the school - take my pictures along too. Imagine the trip will cost about $100 but have decided to take it unless the unexpected happens as its the chance of a lifetime. Am getting more & more interested in the work here and the thought of teaching in Tacoma again according to rule & method is more & more repugnant. So don't know just which way things will turn - as you say we are doing lots of good here and though going along from day to day one is apt to get discouraged at times and wonder if it's worth the effort - for the youngsters do not study and are so irresponsible - most of them - the few who do try though are worthwhile anyway. This community can only be changed through its young people and one can see results here when you go way up the creeks & see conditions where the people have not been touched by the school in any way. And the other schools -
I saw two of them yesterday - one about three miles up Baskin Creek & the other the same distance up the Roaring Fork. Log buildings - benches and a little blackboard in the front end - One had four windows in all - the other six - one had a table for the teacher - the other a split log on end with little short piece across formed the desk! Absolutely no equipment whatsoever - the youngsters have readers & learn reading but writing is not usually taught! Just picture it! Took kodaks of the buildings & will send them as soon as possible. We have been discussing night school lately and are quite enthusiastic about starting it. Mrs. Langmaid now head of the school committee will be here about the middle of October and we are going to discuss it with her. We girls all get along so well together. It is surely fortunate and Mr. Cresswell is always
willing to help as much as possible.

p.del: My last letter was written rather hurriedly Tuesday eve. pa's letter came the next day and was very pleased to get. Hope the California trip is all mapped out & ticket bought by this time. When you go - pa - be sure to plan going south to Los Angeles - or does Mr. St. John live in that section - none of you have mentioned just where he does live. What will Jane do meanwhile? Think I would not know the house if I were there with your newly painted floors and all. The attic too!

div1.p:
Have fields here for my cleaning propensities all right - This attic is a perfect sight and some rainy day Emily & I are going to get busy - Then at school there is an attic where in an old book case is an awful jumble of books - another job for a dark day. The fruit sounds good as it's scarce here - Have not seen any big pears - We had a few small
ones but they were not very good eating & Aunt Lizzie canned most of them. No pa have not been in bathing once and am glad I did not get a bathing suit. There is really no time for play when it comes to cleaning up - prefer seeing the country to dabbing around in Little Pigeon. The weather is summer like and hot except in the mornings & evenings when a nap is comfortable - but am still wearing white shoes and thin dresses - That white dress Jane sent me is so suitable for school and wear first one & then the other most of the time with the gingham in between. At present am clad in my new white georgette waist & light blue skirt - wore my good straw hat to Sunday School too - though fall hats are in evidence even here! The heat has not troubled me at all. Yes am very unusual summer color - red & brown - but flatter myself that the
freckles are not quite so numerous or else my mirror doesn't show them - it's not very good glass you know. I did not burn much on the out. trip last week - At least when I asked the girls about it they said my face was so red all the time they couldn't see any difference. Guess I do look quite healthy - certainly have more color than a year ago - and am still eager for food three times a day at least!

Our fair was a great event though not many in the community turned out for it nor were many things exhibited. It was the first and no doubt next year there will be more interest & it will be more successful. Wednesday morning we went through our program - which was as follows -

list.item:
3. Farm Life - Cora McCarter
(A long winded thing on agriculture & the educated farmer written by some prof at Knoxville & which Miss Whittle was anxious to have read - Cora is my best pupil - is in high school - plans to be a teacher.)
4. Motion Song - Come Little Leaves. by - Primary Class.
5. Drill - Shoo Fly Shoo - Intermediate Class.

9. Dramatizations - Primary Class
a. The Larks
b. King Midas
13. Closing Song - We Thank Thee Oh Father - School.

div1.p:
The drill by the intermediate class was also given at Miss Whittles request and illustrated the use of the fly swatter etc. Emily's little tots were cute. Especially funny were they in the Larks - half a dozen of them represented little birds whom the Mother Bird had to feed - flying off for a worm to give each. The handkerchief drill was just a lot of motions with kerchiefs all ridiculous - My sunbonnet drill went off without a hitch for which I was pleased - We
did not think much of the program - especially on Wednesday when everything was done miserably but it was all right the next day when our company were present. Well after drilling & drilling Wed. a.m. we worked in the building all day & had the youngsters help us instead of recite. We put up the panels making one big room - By the way will you let the girls (Pi Phis) borrow the sketch of the school - it's not well drawn but gives an idea of how things look anyway. We on one side of the hall - the manual training exhibit and on the other baskets. The fireplace was banked with autumn leaves & on mantel were the same and a big fern. Back of the radiators were golden rod & asters. The wild asters here are lovely little things - pale lavender and white - are in bloom now - the
little purple ones are practically gone. Such qualities of golden rod you never saw - there are several varieties here - some much finer & daintier than ours. You know how fond I've always been of it - I get all I want of it now! In the sewing room were two tables of apples - three of the cases filled with preserves of various kinds & canned fruits & vegetables - crocheted work - two coverlids - (not perfect enough to buy) some embroidery - bags made by the little girls & a table of their cookery - peanut bread - cookies & biscuits. In the shop were the vegetables - a huge pumpkin - sage - sugar cane - corn - peppers - onions - beets - Emily had paper chains of various colors in her room - butterflies & little paper things they had made on little tables - autumn leaves - On her desk her waste basket filled with golden rod - I had two corners in the back of my
room filled with writing papers - Japanese lanterns they drew (& good ones too single & in clusters of three) pasted on the blackboard as a border & in the corner by the windows - while in the other corners were their maps - Golden rod & asters stick in the radiators - and on the desk - which was moved back toward the windows as was the piano. Abbie's room was similar & had boughs of autumn leaves for trimming. The building did look pretty & we went home Wed. evening about five weary but pleased - Mrs. Cresswell & Mrs. Bishop both arrive during the day so there was quite a party of us for dinner. Evelyn was busy too everywhere & besides had to bake cakes & pies for the picnic dinner the
next day - Her mother & Aunt Lizzie both helped - Emily and I studied the stars a little & we were early in bed. Did I tell you Emily had a star book? We have found a number of the constellations - take the flashlight turn it on the diagram in the book & then gaze fixedly upward till we begin to see the ones we're looking for - Exclaim & point excitedly study the book again & repeat the noise & gesticulating.

Thursday morning was "brite and fair" and I donned spotless white & my green tie in honor of the occasion. The livestock we had expected dwindled down to a small puppy and a coop of white chickens! However we were kept busy until eleven labelling more canned stuff apples etc. that came in the last thing. At eleven the
school bell was rung - the children assembled for the program in Abbie's room and the audience filled only my room - about fifty. After that we went outside to the back of the schoolhouse when the lunch was set forth on tables - chickens pies cakes - biscuits - bread jelly etc. loads of it everyone helped themselves & sat around & ate. I took a number of pictures during the day & do hope they prove good. The next excitement was the arrival of the baseball team from Sevierville with some of the teachers & girls - they came to the house & had to be shown the exhibit etc. Then about 2:30 the game began - a good close game too - We beat 6 to 4 however. Our team was not a strictly school team but was filled out
with fellows from Sheep Pen - the Glades - Green Brier. The Murphy people yelled vigorously & ours were soon inspired to do the same - In fact the two crowds of girls got pretty personal at times & we had to calm ours a little. The day finally came to a close - the Sevierville crowd departed - Miss Whittle & her two judges also & we turned our thoughts to supper. As everything was taken over to the picnic our prospects appeared nil but Aunt Lizzie found a whole batch of biscuits in the warming oven that had been overlooked - we made chocolate - got out some canned peas - and bethinking ourselves of the girl's display of cookery - Abbie & I rushed over to the schoolhouse for it - However part of it had already found resting places wasn't that the limit? But we packed up what
remained and had a beautiful repast after all. Friday recitations were pretty slim - people were around packing up a good part of the morning so instead of having my recitations in the sewing room as usual I went out on the porch & as it was rather cool early in the a.m. we sat on the edge of the walk in the sunshine. The youngsters thought it great fun! After school Emily & I finished cleaning up while Mr. C. helped load up the wagon with the exhibits for the Sevierville fair which is Monday & Tuesday - Abbie had gone home & Evelyn was busy at the house - then I came home & after sitting on the porch a little with Mrs. Bishop eating apples & cookies - swept downstairs & part of the upstairs. Then cleaned up & proceeded to darn! After dinner we sat around
in the living room - Evelyn played & sang for us - Emily read - Mrs. Bishop crocheted & I finished my darning. So ended another big day.

Yesterday Emily & I bustled around until about eleven and then set forth with lunch & kodak up Baskins Creek - It is not very pretty & is up hill most of the way - the creek is rather dirty & the people all seem so untouched by civilization. We took a steep trail which lead us to the top of a ridge overlooking Roaring Fork and very near the foot of Round Top - We sat here for over an hour - writing in my diary & talking with Emily who wrote a letter - Such a grove of chestnut trees as we were in. These trees are enormous and are beautiful too - loaded with nuts. When we started down to Roaring Fork we came to a field where was a huge apple tree loaded with red fruit - Over
the fence we went and helped ourselves - An abandoned cabin stood in the middle of the field so we were not stealing! The road back was simply beautiful - In one place the side of the mountain was a rocky cliff - several of them in fact and always we followed the creek - many times & oft crossing it on narrow little bridges consisting of two planks - The wild grape vines flourish all along the creek - tree after tree being covered to the very top. As we took our time & made one call along the way & chatted with others it was dark when we reached home though only 6:45. We had tramped about eight of these long miles but frisked around - made hot chocolate - scrambled some eggs and hunted up fresh biscuits - ("light bread" as ( white br raised bread is called here - Aunt
Lizzie never made bread until last winter - everyone makes biscuits & corn bread) Evelyn & her mother were at the Huff's and as Aunt Lizzie had had a spell with her heart that morning we would not let her do anything - After this we went back to the living room - & I copied a couple of poems from the Outlook about the Kentucky mt. people - Then the Bishops got back & in the course of time we were all safe & sound in bed again.

Evelyn & her mother are now on their way to Sevierville as the fair exhibits have to be put in place - Tuesday there will be no school so that the youngsters may have an opportunity to go - Will probably chaperone some of them down -

Have not worn my pleasant hat yet and think I'll not wear it Tues. as it's still dusty & the girls say the crowd is awful - So shall wear my
old gray with my blue suit maybe will wear gray silk gloves & gray shoes -
Am going to have Mary fix my two old georgette waists take out fullness in waist part & sleeves - get ready for New Orleans!

A busy week is ahead of us and as I must plan something for my club girls for tomorrow p.m. find something for B. Y. P. tonight (the subject Divorce was given me but do not care ta to take it somehow!) write a few letters - study a little - guess I must finish this lengthy epistle by bidding you all a fond farewell - I do miss you so much - but we are just too busy for repining! and wouldn't be in Tacoma teaching for anything!! Loads of love - Ruth.

div1.p: On top of the book cases in hall are baskets filled with ferns - over the fireplaces is a large sepia print in brown wood frame of Corat's morning. Above book case at right of hall as you enter is a service flag - filling a large part of the wall space - while at the left on opposite wall is a big American flag - formerly used on flagpole - but torn so abandoned to the closet. We found it & mended it the best we could & had the boys put it up - looks fine too! Back of my desk hangs a big U.S. map & my little silk flag - two or three pictures are on the panel back of the piano - prints and on wall above panel high up hangs a Pi Phi banner - Behind each of my doors is blackboard & between doors - Above are five prints. Between the windows are some colored drawings of Japanese lanterns - Had writing papers along panels of back of room - At present they are all at the at the fair - Under the flag usually sits a flower stand on which is basket with fern - ditto on piano - The two cases in the hall are for the youngster's baskets & pails of lunch. In the sewing room are three tables - benches - blackboard & (I think) three sewing machines & case in corner for their work - In kitchen are oil stoves for the cooking - The shop is very well equipped - the only school in the county that teaches manual training. The water tank is very nice - water pumped from the house - regulation drinking fountain!
